---
title: ‘The Lay Gaze’—Rural Norwegian men’s assessment of others’ health based on
  pictures
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publication</h1>
<article id="csl-bib-container-TKVWAM9U" class="csl-bib-container">

<div id="csl-bib-meta-TKVWAM9U" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-TKVWAM9U" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>About</h1>
    Hervik and Skille conducted a study to understand how rural Norwegian men assess others' health based on their appearance. They interviewed 18 men of various ages, ethnicities, and education levels, showing them pictures of different people. The authors found that most participants believed a slim body indicates good health, a concept known as "healthism." This belief was consistent across the group, despite their diverse backgrounds. However, there were differences in how the men judged the health of elderly and black individuals, suggesting that other factors might influence their perceptions. This study highlights how societal ideas about body image and health can shape personal judgments, which can impact how people view and treat others in everyday life.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-TKVWAM9U" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Keywords</h1>
    Lay Gaze, Bodily Appearance, Health Assessment, Rural Norwegian Men, Healthism
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-TKVWAM9U" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Scientific abstract</h1>
    In  this  article,  we  explore  lay  men's  understanding  of the  relationship  between  other's  bodily  appearance and  health— ‘the  Lay  Gaze’.  We  applied  the  theoreti-cal  concepts  of  biopower,  medical  gaze,  bodyism  and healthism— the ideology where one feature is that a slim body is equivalent to a healthy body— and interviewed 18 adult and elderly men in rural Norway, representing a heterogeneous group regarding age, ethnicity and educa-tion. To explore the interviewees’ subjective perception or ‘gaze’, the interviewees were presented with eight pic-tures of different people. Our main findings were, first, that the sample  of a  relatively heterogeneous  group of adult and elderly lay men in rural Norway talk similarly about body appearance and health and follow the heal-thism discourse with an embedded association between body  appearance  and  health  assessment.  Second,  we found some variation regarding how interviewees define other standards for the elderly and black people.
  </article>
